title: Dear Coleen: My grown-up son cut me off due to rift with grandson
text:

Dear Coleen, I have four sons, all in their late 40s or early 50s. I had them with my first husband who I left 40 years ago. I’ve been remarried for 38 years.

Over the years, my sons have had moments when they’ve refused to speak to me, but my second son took this a step further five years ago when he told me if I didn’t stop talking to his son (with whom he’d fallen out) he’d cut me off.

I tried to explain I loved both him and my grandson, and it was wrong of him to tell me who I can and can’t talk to. He wouldn’t listen and didn’t invite us to our granddaughter’s wedding, cutting us off completely.

Now my husband has cancer (my son knows) and I would like my son to at least get in touch with him – he got on very well with him. But he’s a very stubborn man and blames me for a lot of things that happened in his life.

His father was an abusive ­womaniser. As a single mum, I made decisions I thought at the time were the right ones. It wasn’t easy, but I did my best. Do you have any advice?

(Image: ITV)

Coleen says:

It sounds as if he’s punishing you for everything that’s gone wrong in his life. I’m sure every decision you made all those years ago was made with good intent and you did the right thing getting out of an abusive relationship.

Some people need to find someone to blame for what goes wrong in their life because they can’t look inward and take responsibility. Of course, past experiences shape you and it can’t have been easy for your boys when they were children.

However, while there might be a reason for your son’s behaviour rooted in his past, I don’t think it’s an excuse to punish others.

As an adult, he can make the choice to deal with those issues in a way that helps him and doesn’t destroy his important relationships – through therapy for example.

(Image: Getty)

It’s sad he’s dragged your grandchildren into it, but I don’t think you should stop talking to them – they’re old enough to find the truth and make up their own minds. It’s wrong to blackmail you into cutting ties with your grandson.

If you feel you’ve done everything you can to reach out to him – putting your thoughts in a letter, for example – then you might have to leave the ball in his court and hope he gets in touch with you or your husband.

It sounds as if he’s isolating himself from the family one by one and I hope he doesn’t end up living with regret as that’s a very painful place to be.
description: A worried grandmother asks for advice as her stubborn son blames her for what has gone wrong in his life
